candidates.title: Test otlp exporter in integration scenario
candidates.body:
This is contributing a test that hardens the suite to detect issues when using the otlp exporter in a real-world scenario.

It uses a small mock server that is able to receive the trace exports via plaintext http gRPC. The alternative would have been to spin up the original otlp-collector in docker, but that introduces more dependencies and is harder to assert on.

(This could have detected breakage in #421 which i missed.)

candidates.title: Upgrade Tokio to v1
candidates.body:
*Fixes #420*

I also upgraded these dependencies:
- reqwest
- hyper
- tonic
- prost

candidates.title: Move HTTP-related code into a separate crate
opentelemetry: remove tonic dependency
candidates.body: See #403. This just moves the code into an example -- I'm not sure what else would be relying on these impls?

candidates.title: opentelemetry: replace regex with custom validation logic
feat: otel metric exporter.
candidates.body:
-  Add support for OTLP metrics exporter with `tokio` and `tonic` only.
-  Add transform from record to metric proto types. Need to support `grpcio` in the future.
-  Add `OtlpMetricExporterBuilder` pipeline. Need to figure out a way to combine it with the tracing pipeline. The current blocker is the type parameter from the push controller. Ideally, we gonna need to rewrite the whole pipeline so that when users enable `tracing` only, there will be no type parameter, when users enable the `metrics`, the pipeline will have type parameters.
- Testing has been hard as the OTLP's structure is nested and unordered in general. Need to figure out a way to compare `ResourceMetrics`. 

Probably gonna address the remaining work in other PRs. Thought this is a big enough PR to be reviewed.

candidates.title: Switch Jaeger collectors to use http client trait.
candidates.body:
closes #337 

Added 4 default collector http client implementations(`surf_collector_client`, `reqwest_collector_client`, `reqwest_blocking_collector_client`, `isahc_collector_client`). Note that with any of those enabled. The user can still override the http client setting with `with_http_client`

If the user chooses none of above. They will have to call `with_http_client` to set their own. Otherwise, it will throw a `No http client error`.

Upgrade Note:
- Change the feature from `collector_client` to `isahc_collector_client`.

candidates.title: Move 3rd party propagators and merge exporter into sdk::export
candidates.body:
Fix #361 
Fix #340

This PR:
 - Moved 3rd party propagators into `opentelemetry-contrib/propagator`
 - Added `testing` feature so that we could share test util between crates.
 - Moved `exporter` into `sdk::export`
 - Updated the `opentelemetry-proto`

Upgrade note:
 - For `aws` propagators. Add `opentelemetry-contrib` in your `Cargo.toml`. Choose the feature based on the propagators you need and import them via `opentelemetry_contrib::trace::propagators::<propagators name>`.
 - For types from `exporter` module. Such as `ExportError`. Change the import path from `opentelemetry::exporter` into `opentelemetry::sdk::export`
- For `jaeger` propagators. Add `opentelemetry-jaeger` in your `Cargo.toml`. use `opentelemetry_jaeger::Propagator`
- For `b3` propagators. Add `opentelemetry-zipkin` in your `Cargo.toml`. use `opentelemetry_zipkin::Propagator`

Open question(s):
 - <del>Where should we put the `jaeger` and `b3` propagtor? It's intutive to me that we include them as part of the `opentelemetry-jaeger` or `opentelemetry-zipkin` crate. But Go impl put it in `contrib`</del> Moved zipkin and jaeger propagators into their own crate.

candidates.title: Add actix-http-tracing example
candidates.body: Add an example for actix / tracing integration as this configuration seems to be common

candidates.title: Revisit error handling in trace
candidates.body:
#### Current approaches
Currently, most of the errors in `trace` have been returned via `Box<dyn std::error::Error + Send + Sync + 'static>`. This approach gives users good flexibility to return basically any errors. But it totally depends on user to return meaningful messages in errors to help end user to understand the issue. 

#### Proposed approaches
As discussed in #286, we decided to use `thiserror` library wide to allow multiple level of errors throughout the whole process to send span. 

1. We define a `TraceError` enum to represent any possible errors from `trace` module. It provides some predefined variantion, and we should add more variantions as needed. It also provides two generic variantions `Other` and `Boxed`. `Other` could hold any string and `Boxed` could hold any `Box<dyn std::error::Error + Send + Sync + 'static>`. It allows the user to adapt their currently implementation easily. 

2. We define a `ExporterError` trait, which contains one method to return the name of the exporter. Exporter implementations are engouraged to define their own Error type and implement ExporterError. This allow any exporter implementations to pass their custom errors back to SDK. This should also help narrow down which exporter causes the error when errors being returned.

3. Change function signature to return `TraceError` or `ExporterError` when possible. And use global error handler to handle the rest of errors

candidates.title: feat(otlp): add openssl feature flags for grpcio
candidates.body: `grpcio` has an `openssl` and `openssl-vendored` feature to use `openssl` instead of `boringssl`. This PR exposes these features through an `openssl` and `openssl-vendored` feature﻿ in `opentelemetry-otlp`.

candidates.title: Add wasm support to jaeger
candidates.body:
This PR add another feature `wasm_collector_client` to the `opentelemetry-jaeger` crate which enable a WebAssembly collector.

Note: At the moment of writing Jaeger does not support Option Method requests, that are required by CORS: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Preflight_request. A simple solution is to put Jaeger behind a proxy and handle the request in the proxy.

candidates.title: Implement timeout for force_flush and shutdown.
candidates.body:
- Add the envionment variable support for export timeout.
- Add support of time out when exporting. 
- Added `TraceError` enum, still need to add other error type.

Note that the spec only has configuration for maximum time to export data. So the timeout is based on the export time.

Also included the update from otel-proto

candidates.title: Add tonic for opentelemetry-otlp
candidates.body:
Adds a new gRPC transport layer [tonic](https://github.com/hyperium/tonic) to `opentelemetry-otlp`.

### Summary 

- Use [`tonic`]() as the underlying gRPC transport layer (enabled by default)
- Optional: TLS support using rustls
- Optional: Use the platform's native certificate store
- Optional: Use a blocking client

### Comparison

Project | [hyperium/tonic](https://github.com/hyperium/tonic) | [tikv/grpc-rs](https://github.com/tikv/grpc-rs)
-- | -- | --
Feature name | --features=default | --features=grpc-sys
gRPC library | [`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic) | [`grpcio`](https://crates.io/crates/grpcio)
Transport | [hyperium/hyper](https://github.com/hyperium/hyper) (Rust) | [grpc/grpc](https://github.com/grpc/grpc) (C++ binding)
TLS support | ✅ | ✅
TLS optional | ✅ | 
TLS library | rustls | OpenSSL
Supported .proto generator | [`prost`](https://crates.io/crates/prost) | [`prost`](https://crates.io/crates/prost), [`protobuf`](https://crates.io/crates/protobuf)


![opentelemetry-otlp-tonic](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72995223/99677642-39db9280-2a7a-11eb-9151-6c4168e11b3f.png)

### Configuration

**gRPC transport layer --features=default**

- `default` ([`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic))
Uses [`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic) as the underlying gRPC transport layer.

- `tonic-blocking-client`
Uses a blocking client.

- `tls` ([`rustls`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls))
Allows tonic to use [`rustls`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls) as the underlying TLS client library.
Feature name `tls` adopted from [`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic) (same feature name).

- `tls-roots` ([`rustls-native-certs`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls-native-certs))
Allows  [`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic) + [`rustls`](https://crates.io/crates/rustls) to use the platform's native certificate store when operating as a TLS client.
Feature name `tls-roots` adopted from  [`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic) (same feature name).

Configuration options (features)

`default` ([`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic))

```sh
$ cargo build
```

`default` ([`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic)) + `tonic-blocking-client`

```sh
$ cargo build --features "tonic-blocking-client"
```

`default` ([`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic)) + `tls`

```sh
$ cargo build --features "tls"
```

`default` ([`tonic`](https://crates.io/crates/tonic)) + `tls` + `tls-roots`

```sh
$ cargo build --features "tls tls-roots"
```

**gRPC transport layer --features=grpc-sys**

- `grpc-sys` ([`grpcio`](https://crates.io/crates/grpcio) + [`protobuf`](https://crates.io/crates/protobuf) + [`protobuf-codegen`](https://crates.io/crates/protobuf-codegen) + [`protoc-grpcio`](https://crates.io/crates/protoc-grpcio))
Uses the tkiv/grpc-rs stack (crate grpcio). Warning: The crate name grpcio is misleading. The crate is not associated with the gRPC https://grpc.io project or The Linux Foundation.

Configuration options (features)

`grpc-sys`

```sh
$ cargo build --features "grpc-sys" --no-default-features
```

candidates.title: Move binary propagator and base64 format to contrib.
candidates.body:
* Moved them as they are not part of the spec for now and should not be in main crate when GA. (Moved files and two features from main crate to contrib)
* Moved binary propagator and base64 format into a `binary` module and reexport the public types.
* Also restructure the contrib into two submodule, one for tracing and one for metric.

closes #336

candidates.body: Currently the Datadog example will panic at runtime as there are no exporter http clients configured

candidates.body: Currently these features do not include the required `surf` dependency

candidates.title: Move opentelemetry crate into a directory to flatten the workspace
candidates.body:
This makes working with cargo easier, because many commands (like cargo
check, cargo test) will apply to all crates by default, rather than
only selecting the crate in the top-level directory.

candidates.title: Fix reqwest feature dependency for zipkin
candidates.body:
Currently `opentelemetry-zipkin` will not compile with the non-blocking reqwest configuration as `reqwest` is not specified as a dependency.

Fixes #321

candidates.title: Add feature requirements to docs
candidates.body:
* Add `rustdoc-args = ["--cfg", "docsrs"]` and `#[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "<feature-name>")))]` to have features show up on docs.rs
* Move module docs in private modues to their primary structs (`Context`, `Tracer`, etc) as they were currently hidden.
* allow `private_doc_tests` as we currently use private modules to conform to spec layout without forcing users to go through layers of modules.
* Fix some broken doc links

candidates.title: Add MSRV
candidates.body:
* Support rust 1.42.x for core crate and trace exporters (metrics exporters are still unstable and `protobuf` does not support 1.42)
* Make small inconsequential syntax changes to support backwards compatibility
* Ensure dependencies support 1.42 and remove unused default features

candidates.title: Include all features for docs.rs
candidates.body:
The documentation on docs.rs currently only includes default features. This leaves out the metrics feature.

This PR adds the following block to all `Cargo.toml` files that define features, which enables all features for the docs.rs build:

```toml
[package.metadata.docs.rs]
all-features = true
```

See docs about this: https://docs.rs/about/metadata

I ran `cargo doc --all-features` locally for all those projects to ensure the build works.
